39393767.review:
Absolutely wonderful, fun experience with reliable, stable internet connectivity. I would reccomend the dev put his resources towards new team members as this project is more than worth investing in.

One funny thing I realized, was by applying any form of untrained, uninformed real-world strategy in a sword fight, would kill the difficulty. Trying to react to things in a videogamey sense didn't work out, and the game became fairly punishing, but as soon as I applied anything I've seen from any random fencing match or HEMA event, the game got far easier, as enemies tend to swing in a less predictable, but easily countered method. 

I would suggest the dev look into researching historical european martial arts, as it would help ballance a game in which you can apply these tactics. I know this isn't a simulator or anything, but anyone who's seen a fencer can demolish this gam e in a few hours, at least the main boss and multiple of the dungeons.

39336708.review:
Based on 2 sessions of this with a friend and we've had an amazing time.

Massive variety of weapons which get upgraded through chests depending upon your success in the dungeon, the ability to tweak your strengths (and weaknesses) through stat up points, and a class system.

The standard dungeons were a lot of fun and got us into how the mechanics worked out, but in the nightmare dungeon, it really shone. We changed terrain from inside dungeon walls, to an ice cave, went outside in the rain and had to run a gauntlet of several orcs charging us along a long bridge.

I played this with a mix of the locomotion types, and while I like thumbpad based locomotion, it was worth dropping this for teleporting as it meant I could play for longer. The third type with arm swinging seems well weighted in terms of speed 
 and maneuverability and I'll be trying that next.

Challenging but not overly so, fast loading times and joining a multiplayer game with a friend was easy.
Very immersive and the first time i've felt 'this is the VR RPG I've been waiting to play'

39180094.review:
wow!  I've had this game in my library for months, and have tried jumping in every now and then, but I never could seem to really figure out what I was supposed to be doing.  But last night I purchased a second copy so my wife and I could hop into this game together, and holy cow, this game came to life for us in coop!   The sense of adventure and the deep creepy atmosphere of the dungeon just ooze from every corner of this game.  The first time we heard the sound of an approaching ghost, and seeing the light of it pierce the darkness at the end of the hallway, my wife was cowering behind me, and I had to be a true knight and step up and protect her!  :) it was awesome!  The randomly generated dungeons make for a new and fun experience every time.  The rooms are widely varied and the traps are fun to figure out how to navigate.  At one point, we both had to get prone onto the ground to crawl through a space that we discovered to find out what was hiding in there.  

The visuals in this are stunning.  Several times we both stopped and just gushed about how nice the lighting and shadows looked.   Everything looks very clean and polished.  

Finishing a dungeon gives you all kinds of cool loot, mostly in the form of treasure chests that you get to open in your weapons room and provide you with upgrades and new weapon unlocks.   There are specific challenges inside each dungeon that are not mandatory, but if you complete them, you get extra loot at the end for accomplishing those goals.  

This game is fantastic, and definitely worth a look.  It made me lifetime dream of being able to actually walk through the halls of a dungeon with a sword and shield in my hands a reality, and I am so excited to get back in there and keep finding loot!

39136466.review:
I've done one playthrough of this game with a friend of mine, and I can speak for the both of us if I'd say we enjoyed it a lot. There's not too much variety in monsters and rooms, but having them randomized does help a lot.
We started figuring out spawn points of items relatively fast in rooms we had already been in.
Climbing in this game is extremely fun to do; and we never said no to an opportunity to do so.
Melee combat is a bit weird; but using guns and magic was extremely fun!

[h1]Things I liked:[/h1]
+ The randomly generated dungeons
+ Climbing in the dungeons
+ Looking for hidden treasure everywhere
+ Controls are smooth
+ Progression system
+ The magic is extremely fun to use


[h1]Some downsides:[/h1]
- All monsters in a room spawn in a single wave, so you know you are safe once you kill the wave.
- This one is kinda personal: I got motion sick when using my touchpad to move. (But no fear, teleportation is a thing too!, which I switched to after my first dungeon)
- There's only a small amount of different room layouts. But still plenty to have hours of fun! 
- Melee combat feels weird (swinging with weapons)

Keep in mind that this is written during Early Access. This game has amazing an potential, and I really enjoyed my playthrough (killing the final boss) with my friend. I will be returning to this game for sure!


[h1]tl;dr[/h1]
It's a fun game for €20. You can tell it is still in development, but I've played about 4 hours co-op with a friend of mine and we had tons of fun exploring the dungeons.

38925089.review:
Very promising, but rough around the edges. From what I've read, those edges are getting less sharp every update.

If you've played [i]Vanishing Realms: Rite of Steel[/i] and enjoyed it, you have a lot to be excited about here.

[i]VR Dungeon Knight[/i] doesn't have the best name, and the tutorial might even cause you to worry, like it did me, but try to push past it--there's a lot of correct choices being made in the grand scheme of it all. In the game, you will traverse a dungeon that is randomly generated and encounter enemies, loot, traps, and the occasional boss. Aside from normal movement (through teleportaion, trackpad or arm swinging), you can climb vines and ladders and physically crouch to get through small spaces.

Before you start each dungeon, you can go to the weapon room and build your loadout, anything you'd like that you can hold. Bows and arrows, daggers, swords, claymores, shields, lanterns, magic tomes to cast spells from, health potions and the like are at your disposal, ands these items can level up as you earn loot from running the dungeon, albeit in a somewhat randomized, lootbox fashion (don't worry, there are no microtransactions). There is special gear that I have no idea how to unlock yet, and there is armor that you can buy with the gold you find to provide you with different looks along with traits that can influence your playstyle.

Combat is pretty good for VR, but still stands to improve, at least in the animation department. You're able to parry enemy attacks using weapons or a shield, and slaying enemies nets your character experience. Your character levels as you gain experience, which, once you unlock the ability to, you can distribute stat points into dexterity, strength and intelligence to improve your character.

So far it's enjoyable, but it might not be polished to the point that it's for everyone just yet. I think it'll get there, though.

38912646.review:

Combat feels visceral and meaty and just the right amount of scary. So far I have only fought Orcs one at a time with a sword and shield. There are several other weapons available - dagger, pistol, spellbook, bow & arrow - right from the beginning

[b]Negatives[/b]

None so far

38497934.review:
While this game is a lot of fun in solo mode, with a ton of replayability, it really shines in co-op with a friend.  Be a knight, a wizard or a rogue wielding a vast array of weapons.  Make smart decisions on what you bring with you based on chosing a short dungeon or a long.

It's easiest to describe this game as a VR rogue-light dungeon crawler.  It's all about repetition of dungeons to improve your gear and your character, and the RPG elements in the game so far add enough variety to keep you coming back, letting your character feel like it's 'yours'.

Where most VR games currently struggle to top 3-4 hours of playability, this one has the potential to keep you immersed for far longer than that.  It's a must have for an VR enthusiast!

38071960.review:
I really like this game, I can tell it's going to be fantastic and I'm glad to be a part of it. I've only played 2 hours but i'm liking what I see. 

Keep in mind what you're walking into - a VR dungeon grind, similar to diablo or poe, but not nearly as developed. It's Early access after all. 

The best part about it is the atmosphere, it achieves a darkness and "dungeon" feel that is really thrilling to play through. The enemies are fun as well, I enjoy finding them and having to react. I also really like the movement between rooms, the randomization, and the combat-parry system is very enjoyable, though not perfect.

I think one thing would be nice is more of a HUD system. I know they're a bit immersion breaking but I think concessions toward gameplay are necessary.  Perhaps health, a minimap, skill display (see below), arrow/ammo count...

I'd also like to see more customization of my character. The classes and 3-stats that I've seen are a good start, but the classes themselves feel a little bland. From what I can tell, they support your weapon/loadout selection but don't really change the gameplay much. I think a "skill" system that would really give each class a "branch" to be explored would be great. I haven't bought a class yet (I keep dying in stupid ways like water or the axes+light damage and collecting the money is tough!) so this could be unnecessary, I will update if so. 

I'd also like to see more in the way of "loot" and inventory. I think that there's some aversion to a more typical game inventory (slot or weight limited) given that we're in VR, but I'd like gameplay more than absolute dungeon-immersion. I know there's a blacksmith or something, though I haven't found him yet. Again, this might be unnecessary criticism. But along those lines, I'd love a "collection" of some sort that could be sold or built, and perhaps built into a crafting system. Again, I'm looking forward to the blacksmith and what that brings. 

With that, enemies should drop items/loot right? It's why we're dungeon crawling after all! 

So overall, I'm looking forward to progressing - unlocking more weapons, getting a class, getting the blacksmith and spending "tokens," figuring out what the red-lantern does... I'm very excited to see this game evolve. I hope the online community grows too - right now I see it tends to hover around 5-10 people online in the evenings of eastern US. 

One last thing... I don't like how my loadout is reset every time I die... It kinda kills me. 

Thanks for the game BlackJard Softworks!

Edit: Also, DESTRUCTIBLES!!!! The rooms feel so empty, and it's frustrating to explore for no reason - I feel like I should just take the first door I find. I'm not sure how that would impact performance, but I think it'd go well with the improved looting/collection/crafting system I suggested above :)

37786004.review:
This is the most enjoyable VR game I have played so far. I would recommend it to anyone that has a VR headset.

Good things:
- Many different locomotion options (Normal trackpad controls, teleportation and arm swing. I prefer the normal trackpad controls as it allows for navigation whilst attacking, as arm swing controls make it quite hard to attack and walk at the same time)
- Lots of different weaponry for different styles (Melee, ranged and magic. You can use multiple if you want too, and they are all fun to use)
- Very atmospheric, it reminded me of a horror game the first time I played it, and it added a lot to the tension. Makes it very immersive too.
- High replayability compared to lots of VR games (Randomly generated dungeon, blackmark tokens and chest upgrades. Co-op adds more to this too)
- The way gold, EXP books and tokens are hidden makes it fun to search rooms.
- At the time of writing this, you don't have to wait long for a co-op game (When playing with random people). I have also found it easy to add some people using the forums to do dungeons with too.
- The developer is extremely active, and updates the game frequently. You can see him replying to lots of reviews and stuff in the forums quite regularly.
- Very fun, and it feels like a proper game when most VR games feel like demos or not full games.

Things that need improving:
- You can teleport past traps and parkour parts of the dungeon (I am not sure how you would go about fixing this, as I assume the teleport option is there for those that get motion sick easily. Perhaps make a mode where you can enable teleportation, but you get 50% exp or something? So if you play with 100% exp you have to dodge the traps and do the parkour)
- Magic AOE gets in the way of vision (If you are playing in co-op and one player uses the fire AOE spellbook, it is very hard to see the enemy that is in the fire, so if you are using melee then it is difficult to attack and defend)
- Animations of the enemies in co-op (It is hard to tell when an enemy is blocking or attacking when multiple people are attacking an enemy at once, as the enemy displays the animation that shows it has got hit repeatedly. Makes melee quite difficult in teams, but when there is no co-op, it is a lot easier to tell what the enemy is doing)
- Only 1 type of enemy in each room (I would like it if there were mixed enemies, so you would have to fight melee orcs while also dodging skeleton archer arrows)
- Nightmare mode is too easy (I have seen a lot of people say the same, I have yet to lose in nightmare mode. It is still very fun though, but there isn't much risk of dying unless you are completely new to the game)
- The arm swing navigation is default (I found it quite hard to navigate during the tutorial. I think it would be nice if it was possible to choose the preferred locomotion option before the tutorial, and think it would give new players a better grasp on how to play the game, and not turn them away from the game if they don't like the arm swing movement)

What I would like to see in the future:
- Puzzle rooms (There are kind of puzzle rooms already where you have to search for the key, but I wouldn't class it as a fully fledged puzzle. I like the part where you have to search for the 3 lanterns to unlock the chamber of heroes, that kind of thing would be a good addition to the regular dungeons), hidden doors and stuff like that. This game has a TON of potential.
- A rise in difficulty (Especially co-op)

P.S: Sorry for all the brackets

37263270.review:
This is the most under-appreciated VR game on Steam. It is easily the most engaging, immersive, and simply downright fun VR game I have played as of yet. I have always been a fan of dungeon crawlers, and VR Dungeon Knight encapsulates that perfectly, from the terrifying (at first, at least) atmosphere right down to the rewarding sense of character progression given both by a system of leveling up and statting points towards your style of play, unlocking new armor-sets to fully support your style of play, and obviously the loot system, allowing you to unlock and upgrade new weapons. Now, lets get down to the pros and the cons :

Pros:

*Incredibly atmospheric and immersive art style
*An awesome and active developer who is constantly updating the game, with both gameplay and bug-fixes!
*Performs very well, with barely any framerate inconsistencies (Especially given the new update as of Nov. 23rd)
*Infinite replayablility, with procedurely generated dungeons with two difficulties (Normal for just a quick dungeon crawl 
     to blow a few minutes, nightmare for those seeking a truly thrilling and tense crawl)
*A mind-boggling amount of environments, all of them beautifully built. Even though it may seem immersion-breaking to  
     from one moment be in a dark, creepy castle to end up in archaic ruins, only to then find yourself in a snow-blanketed 
     forest, it honestly isn't. All it does is give variety to your experience, and ensure you never get bored of your 
     surroundings.
*A large variety of different monsters for you to dissasemble on your adventures, all with great animations, sound effects, 
     and even, to some extent, fighting manuevers (Attempting to parry, attacking from different directions, etc)
*The pure fear that comes in your first few dungeons as you slowly walk through the dark environments, and inevitably 
     run into your first baddie and have a couple heart attacks. This effect fades away after time after you learn which areas
     can actually have baddies, how the baddies behave, etc.

Cons (There aren't many) :

*Not many players! Dungeon crawling by myself is fun, but there is never anyone in the public lobbies to do some co-op 
     with. You have to pre-group with people from the forums or have friends IRL who also play it.
*You cant save a load-out of gear, making you re-equip all your weapons and utility items after every dungeon.
*Not enough variety with the bosses! The only mini-boss is the giant armored orc, and the only end-of-dungeon boss is 
     the necromancer dude - An exact, if smaller and weaker, replica of the final boss fight.

All in all, it is a fantastic game that I look forward to playing more and seeing more of what the developer has to offer for this game. I have never written a steam review before, but the entire journey from my first dungeon, with no armor set, a level 1 lantern in one hand and a short sword in the other, all the way to now at lvl 16 with my level 2 Marked Katana, Dungeon Knight and Ranger armor sets, and my trusty lvl 20 crossbow and lvl 18 bow has driven me to finally write one. 

(TL:DR -  Get the game. Honestly. It is, in my humble opinion, the absolute best and most replayable experience on VR as of now)

36582806.review:
A complete and utter blast to play with a friend. From it's rough graphics and cumbersome controls it sets the bar low in the tutorial, only to impress again and again as you delve into the depths of the game play and design. This is an excellent take on building a game around fun satisfying game play when you don't quite have the graphics and gimmicks to win on aesthetics alone.

I'll keep it simple-

Pros-
Awesome platforming
Some great puzzles and mechanics that you really only pick up on with a good chunk of time into the game
Lot's of content (Sure it's procedural but it's diverse enough to go for quite a while before it feels overdone)
Surprise boss fights!
Innovative implementation of weapons (holstering, spells, dual wielding)
A simple but clever approach to a class system
Despite tooltips and tutorials there's a lot to learn on your own (a major plus in my case)
Movement system is well done, though it does take quite a while to get comfortable with.

Cons-
Graphics can be rough, and when all put together things can look a bit glitchy (clipping through trees, gear on characters, occasional glitching into walls and getting stuck or having characters fly at you randomly at crazy high speeds)
The levels though randomized get boring at a point, when you know where all the doors and potential hidden spots are
Melee combat against enemies is lacking (very hack and slash, no real control or subtlety to it)
Having to re-gear every time you die is a bit of a time waster

Two improvements would take this from good to amazing:
Modding- User created levels could really expand the content of this game
Better melee- being able to block with weapons, enemies blocking you, different enemy behaviors (think Gorn)

36555497.review:
A fun little dungeon crawler that has sucked away way more hours than I would have thought. Very immersive, you will find yourself slowly checking around every corner, climbing up and over pits, and even going prone to fit through some spots. Overall I have had loads of fun, especially for the low asking price. If you like D&D and have VR, give this a shot.

Details/specifics and feedback below:

The enemies are always threatening, as you can't take many hits, and with no healing (Minus some self regen from red to orange post fight), you regret taking damage. There are a decent number of types, although it is only 1 type per room currently. The rooms. My goodness, there are alot of them. You will eventually see them all, but from the giant open pillars, snowy mountain, open forest in addition to a whole host of dungeon rooms, you will be surprised at how long that it takes. Soom of the rooms are breaks from the action, with no enemies, giving a chance for you to explore and look for loot, or even the key to continue. You do eventually pick up on which rooms are like this, but it took a while, so even a transition room with no enemies can make you cautious.

Loot system helps to keep the tension, as you only get upgrades/weapon unlocks IF you clear a dungeon. Decent weapon and playstyle variety, thanks to armor sets and levels. The current build for weapon holsters is great, 1 on the back, 3 at the waist. Feels great to pull arrows from a quiver on the back. Weight has an impact on locomotion, but I couldn't feel any difference with teleport. Give the arm motion running a try, feels very nice to charge up to an enemy and have them taste cold steel.... even if when you crouch or drop prone, it can look and feel funny.

Magic is boring but practical, as you just hold trigger to charge up an attack, and sit there waiting for it to power up. Could really use some hand movements, perhaps to reduce the casting time. You can waggle your way to victory with swords, but common, immersive yourself damnit! Take some proper swings.  A lack of arrows (If not a ranger), or findable equipment mid run can hurt some weapon choices (Why take a crossbow with 4 shots over a spell book with unlimited casts?) Nit picky, but the short bow is extremely small looking in your hands. Really could use a long bow. Same for the katana, the handle is massive.

Co-op is hilarious, as it is equal parts buggy as it can be fun, but as has been stated is a work in progress. I have had the game spawn us into the darkness outside of a room and trapped us (Had to restart game, as there is no exit dungeon or menu), enemies ignored me for agro (Including the final boss who spawned!) and accidently equipped my weapon onto my partner's belt... even though they had a sword there. Having a room to kill enemies while you wait for the game to find a buddy is a superb idea, although you are limited with what spawns in the room. Would be nice to keep what you equip into here. Or for that matter, when you die or finish a run.

Once a room is clear of baddies, the tension is lifted, as every enemy heads towards you when you agro one. It would make a huge difference if I had to slowly check each corner for some of these rooms. Some sort of agro radius that prevents all of them from coming would help that. There is a massive need for some traps to be added to some of the "safe" rooms to help this same problem. Some more mini-bosses would be a great addition (Think Diablo... standard mob but more health, randomized name above its head and bam, your golden). Throw-able weapons would be excellent as well. Once you own all the armors and weapon upgrades, there is nothing to do with gold/chests, which puts a cap on the very good replayablility. Perhaps a merchant which allows you to spend gold on healing or revive potions?

Phew. If you read through all of that, then props. Keep up the good work Blackjard Softworks! All one of you!

36293390.review:
honestly this game is a blast. I own it for oculus rift and played co-op with my friend for a short while.
Pros/Cons


Graphics
Pros:
Dungeons feel mostly unique although some rooms are completely pointless.
Weapons look alright
Enemies are somewhat varied (In my 2 hours playing i've seen about 6 different enemy types)
There seems to be some funny graphical error when playing co-op where your friend has 4 hands instead of 2.

In-Game options
Pros:
You can swap from head-direction to hand direction movement
Shadows/Scaling options to make it look more realistic
You can turn off body images so you only see your inventory when looking down rather than a body/legs which can reduce motion sickness.
Cons:
Wish we had options to set if the user has oculus or vive. Certain gameplay elements like climbing are difficult when using snap turning and it makes you lose grip/fall in game (primarily for oculus due to sensor placement).


Weapons: 
Pros: Varied amounts like pistols, arrows, sword and shield, spear, magic spells, etc. (I think roughly 12 weapons currently)
Cons: 'leveling' the weapon feels good with the chest animations and sounds, but falls so short in terms of power and utility. My level 9 Lantern is the exact same as my level 1 was. I also read on the forums that getting higher level magic spells has ABSOLUTELY NO IMPACT on its damage, it only increases the books weight.

This is a big one...
For Oculus Users, the magic spells you can cast from wielding a book are always misaligned with your hand.
Using magic forces you to angle your hand further down than the hand model moves in game, causing a lot of immersion breaking frustration.
2 Handed weapons handle weirdly; Basically, if you grasp the weapon with your left hand and hold the trigger button, it'll enable 2 hand wielding, where your second hand grabs the higher part up on the weapon instead of the lower piece. This factor makes swinging 2h weapons awkward.

Classes
Pros:
The current available list of classes feel impactful when used.
Cons
small selection
Ranger feels near impossible to enjoy without the class outfit as you are constantly running out of arrows.

Stat distribution
Pros:
descriptive so when utilized you know what each stat improves.
Cons:
Having character levels should be a more focused point. Lazily strolling through a dungeon, leveling, throwing a few points into a slot doesn't feel super rewarding without actually EARNING something, (IE. A skill or cosmetic change).

Inventory
Pros 4 total slots seems like plenty
easy access locations
In co-op you can share your weapons with your ally. He got a level 3 iron shield and you're stuck with a level 1 wooden shield? he can pick his off the wall and throw it your way to use!

Combat
Pros: you can shield bash, peak around corners and shoot ranged weapons and dual wield multiple swords and daggers.
Cons: Initial impact with enemies may involve glitching out. The enemy will stutter back and forth taking damage and spewing copious amounts of blood until they fall over and explode
The health 'meter' you have is located on your belt so if you don't look down at your crotch you wont know how healthy you are; and even if you do check there is not a very accurate way for the game to tell you how much health you have in numbers. The health meter simply says things like "Very healthy" or "Wounded- Heavy"
I feel that a number or percentage visual located in a more convenient place without cluttering your view would be ideal. Maybe something like checking your pulse in game can reveal how much damage you've suffered.

Exploration
Pros: This blows my mind. Turning sideways to slide through crevices or going prone to crawl through some caverns. This game ALWAYS has you moving, but doesnt make you feel like you've ran a marathon.
Its action packed or can be played as a complete rogue-lite experience and you can sneak around every dungeon and enemy and get bonus points for doing it!
Cons: Although there are tons of new areas to discover i have also experienced many bugs playing this. One bug was entering a room with absolutely no exit door or any door that would open (no enemies or monster locks or key guarded doors in the vicinity) and another bug was entering a completely pitch black room; Both of those rooms only occurred during co-op sessions forcing us to restart the game.

Overall i really enjoy this game and would recommend trying it out with a friend for some engaging co-op
Its very true this game is getting regular updates from the wonderful One Person Dev Team. So, if this review isnt helping to sway your opinion, keep an open mind for the future because VR Dungeon Knight does show promise as a leading rogue-lite rpg for VR.

36179744.review:
This game is an excellent dungeon crawler. Supporting multiple playstyles, there is a large amount of replayability compared to other VR dungeon crawler titles. The stealth and ranged weapons feel well done although be warned that stealth can be midly physically tiring. Magic feels a bit slow and simplistic even with heavy skill investment, but it is nevertheless is usually fun to use and requires you to be on edge. That is, unless you spam charged lightning bolts so you can stun lock enemies. Melee is also fairly simple, but generally fun given the extensive variation of melee weapons both one and two handed. In addition, the armor (purchasable via coins you find by exploring the dungeon), skill points, and weapon level progression add a sense of purpose to playing the game, further increasing replayability. 

One of my favorite parts of this game is the movement system. It combines touchpad movement and armswinger modes  to give a very immersive system where you feel you are in complete control of where you go unlike most variations of touchpad, armswinger, or teleportation.

36174949.review: Amazing game. Love the way its done, its one of the best expirences in VR. The only down side is that me and my friend killed the boss in 30mins of gameplay but there still a lot to do. Keep the good work. Looking forward for more content.

36143846.review:
So at 10 hours of gameplay, I feel i can safely write an accurate review. This game is a must have for anyone whom enjoys fantasy or dungeon crawler games. I have been playing on the rift, and the controls work perfectly. 

Graphics: 7/10
Gameplay: 8/10
Customization: 9/10
Multiplayer 9/10
Replay Value: 9/10

Pros:
-Procedurally generated dungeons mean a new experience everytime you play
-The immersive experience of this game is out of this world
-There is a lot to explore and uncover in the game. At times you will have to crawl on your hands and knees to navigate the world. You will have to carry a torch through dimly lit rooms, and climb vines (like in legend of zelda, or any RPG)
-If you get treasure chests, the loot is kept in your private weapon vault, and you can level up weapons and find new gear by completing challenges in dungeons. 
-The gold you find in dungeons is used to buy classes or amor, which you can unlock and switch between before entering dungeons.
-The "feel" of the different weapons are all unique and each feel as though they require some skill to master.
-You CAN NOT just swing your sword around and kill units, you must time your hits, block attacks, and dodge out of the way -- to successful outskill the enemy units.
-There are a ton of different locomotion options available to players.
- The game has magic, melee, and ranged weapons. All of these are a lot of fun to play around with.
- Minibosses and dungeon bosses are a real kick when they show up. 
- You really can tailor your experience to be however you see fit in RPGS. You can run in and hack and slash, or you can use spells to lay traps for your opponents, or you can snipe orcs with bows from range. 
- If playing in multiplayer, you really have to communicate with your partners. 
-There are updates occuring often and the dev seems really invested in this game.

Cons
- Only 2 player Coop is available at this time. It is a shame because I have several friends and we would all like to play in the same session. 
- The music is alright ( most of the time I find myself listening to adventuring music through spotify)
- The player animations in Coop are wonky, almost elastic looking
- You will get some jump scares (could be a good thing, but up to personal preference)
- Some weapons feel more polished than others

36021446.review:
Great VR dungeon crawler that throws room after room at you until you complete your run. Some rooms contain puzzles, others contain monsters, and most contain hidden treasures. Some 'rooms' are actually large outside environments or require some climbing or even crawling to get ahead, which is always fun in VR. And believe it or not, but this is the game that finally taught me to appreciate armswinger movement controls.

There's a large random element to the whole gameplay, and no two runs will be the same. Still, you may get unlucky and see the same room run after run. A game like this really shines with variety, and that is something that still needs a little more time to grow, as currently you'll often be fighting orcs (in two color varieties!) or searching for that key on the bookshelf again.

Still, I'm excited to discover what the future brings for this game, and even in its current state it is one of the best (and most fun) VR Dungeon crawling experiences you'll find. 35936282.review:
Even with all of the glitches and such with no real depth in terms of story I have enjoyed this so much and played it for many many hours. 

The graphics style is GREAT. The silly stupid number of environments is AWESOME and they are so varied and interesting that even after playing for over 8 hours I am not sure if I have seen them all. I remember going through a cave thinking it was just a normal cave and then there was a stupid budda stature with a red glowing light on its face in the dark and I FREAKED. The ambient sound/music is very very good as well and keeps the mood. 

The combat, while buggy at times, is fun and I love where the difficulty is at. Having enemies dynamically attack or block would be nice but to be honest if I were to run it solo and they did that I dont know if I could beat a blue dungeon.

TLDR list

Pros
-Graphics are fun and environments are super varied with hidden rooms and treasure to be found
-Large number of melee/ranged weapons and 3 unique spellbooks you can unlock each with 2 levels of spells that can be cast with different effects. With the different classes there is tons to unlock.
-Fairly varied and unique cast of enemies.
-Ambient sound is amazing.
-Puzzles, while simple, are entertaining and searching diligently for hidden gold/xp/tokens rarely goes unrewarded in red dungeons. 

Cons
-Bugs are fairly common
-Certain sound effects dont fit or are too loud
-Great voicing and environments makes me sad there are not really any NPCs and that the storyline is so shallow
-Combat can get boring, although dev is making swinging weapons wildly less effective soon
-Many things such as hosting or joining a private game do not work most of the time and can make it hard to play with a friend.
-I feel like many things need to have a more detailed explanation via text menu or advanced turorial.
-Having a menu to exit the dungeon at will would be nice. 

Early Access Score : 8/10

If this was a fully released title: 4/10

Dev seems active and very cool. Hope he keeps up the great work! This is one of my new underdog favorite VR games :)

35784671.review:
First things first, I really want to like this game! It presents an atmosphere I can get into and has dungeons that actually have some atmosphere and some amount of variety.

That said, I'd like to lay out the things I found very frustrating.

There need to be more options for locomotion. Specifically I want controller-based movement (point controller to the "forward" direction), which was promised a long time ago. It's painful to have to move my thumb around the touch pad just to maintain course while turning my head. This is compounded during a fight. Very immersion breaking. :( I might as well use my uber teleportation powers that would consistently get me where I want to go without having to look
Speaking of which:
[Personal pet peeve] IMHO teleportation is not immersive, no matter how many people play the "no motion sickness" card. I think if the player can teleport, that should be a natural thing the character can do and should be explained somehow. I have nothing against being able to teleport! I have lots of things against offering it as the primary mode of movement in a game about a lowly knight that can not only barely wield a sword, but barely knows magic, if at all! Yet you're somehow a teleportation wizard! And THEN you're ALSO given the option of literally gimping yourself and NOT teleporting [/PPP]
You're not the only one that does this, but just wanted to put that out there. ;) Maybe your character could have some kind of teleportation pacifier that they pick up from the config room ;P Lol, that'd be awesome

I also would like to use the bow, but I've been spoiled by better implementations (no offense). The bow in this game has such a tiny draw length that I feel like I'm using a cheap sucker dart bow from a dollar store. I understand the need to keep things functional for smaller audience members, but perhaps things like this can be auto-scaled based on player height?
Second weapon gripe: How use two hands for two hand sword? I tried gripping (which swaps hands), triggering, menuing, swiping/pressing touchpad, etc. Could not figure out. Will not use. Damage bonus aside, I'm here for immersion. :P Maybe change name to "Long Sword" and encourage pairing with empty hand?

Please keep that in mind... especially since the tech is not yet mainstream. People have less and less patience for poorly implemented VR mechanics. I've noticed this way more in my VR mates than in myself. One of them made it through your intro stage, and immediately quit because he was convinced solely from that that the controls were bad, the configuration options were bad, and the story telling, graphics, sounds, music, atmosphere (things that other POS VR publications on the store don't even offer) didn't help to hold it up... because mechanics make a game and without them the game wasn't worth playing.
You can hardly blame them though. I mean, you can only tolerate so many cheap VR games that are truly bad and somehow make it to the store because "forget quality, we NEED VR games" before you start getting use to dropping a game early because it's "probably bad".  :/

The atmosphere of the dungeons was very well done! Was super creeped out when I went into one for the first time ... and was heckled for having brought no weapons to the party. Kudos for that little easter egg! Bad kudos for not telling me ahead of time and not allowing me to confirm my poor life choice. :P Continuing from this experience, it was also made apparent to me (or maybe not) that you cannot LEAVE a dungeon you've entered... unless you kill the game. :(

All in all, this is definitely Early Access, but you're making a very promising game here! I wanted more from Vanishing Realms... but as the name suggested, it vanished. Hope yours goes above and beyond! We need better dungeon crawlers :D

Despite the drawbacks, I recommend this game to support a developer that actually made it this far with their game and hope they keep it up. :) You know, unlike other developers that were clearly here for the cash grab. :P

35608086.review:
This game is like Rogue in VR.   As a newly selected `Dungeon Knight' you have been selected to fight your way through randomly generated dungeon rooms collecting gold and experience until eventually you have enough skill (and equipment) to vanquish the big bad thing.

There are several types of room, some fairly maze-like, others short twisty passages.   Castle like areas lead to dripping caves, then to misty forest or vast chambers.   Water filled passages with stepping stones, or low crawlways that you physically need to get down on the floor to navigate.  Throughout the dungeon your light seems to be swallowed by the very air around you.   And then there are the monsters.

My first trip through the dungeon I neglected to pick up any weapons before entering, and spent my entire trip through ~10 connected rooms running and teleporting, trying to keep from being killed.   I haven't made the same mistake again.

Four inventory slots make for a difficult set of choices.   Shield or bow?   Sword or knife?   Do I carry a lamp with me or rely on whatever light the dungeon itself contains.

There is a thief skill, climbing vines, a little magic, and mostly fighter class stuff.

With 30 hours into the game I still play it regularly, I enjoy coop mode mostly but still love to run the dungeons by myself every now and then.  I am going to make a list of "bug, likes, dislikes, want to see" from my personal prospective of the game, I do highly recommend this game. 

Likes:  

1. The music at times will make your heart skip a beat as if you are being chased or hiding from jason voorhees himself, especially in nightmare dungeons.
2. It is great that you are able to choose the way you  move around in the game rather it be teleport or arm swing or both. 
3. The developer is updating the game and listening to peoples comments.
4. There are different classes, A good variety of weapons and a level system for weapons and character stats.
5. Some of the levels are well made and make you really want to look around, The developer has made exploration of the bigger maps very satisfying visually with things like alters or well placed statues or broken doors. It makes you want to look around instead of just run to the next room like some of the simpler levels.
6. combat is very satisfying and keeps you guessing where to block, you really need to watch your opponents. 

Dislikes: - everything i write here is just miner things I have seen, Also it is not to say that these will not be fixed as the game is still in early access mode-

1. The levels that have the night sky are good levels but the night sky needs work as it is very grainy.
2. There is a certain room that is obnoxiously huge with pillers everywhere and almost always has enemys, the problem is that you are stuck in that large (barely visable room) for a set amount of time trying to find a door and there is nothing to visually satisfy you at all, It is just pillers, walls, floor, ceiling.
3. So far there is no fall damage implimented in the game, I see many people just speed climb everywhere and loot rooms but when they are done they just fall because they know it will not hurt, I believe falling from 13 or more feet might cause a little damage and help with the immersion in the game.  -honestly i would laugh till i was red in the face if my coop partner fell from the top of the inverted level to his death.-

bugs: - A list of things I have found

9.  more staffs to use.

35586125.review:
Active and responsive developer which listens to fans and releases updates at a nice rate from what I can see.  He is currently reworking the combat, which is a good sign considering it could use some improvements to make it feel more responsive and realistic.  The current implementation is in the right direction though as it does discourage players from just waggling to win.

Currently there is a decent amount of weapons and player power progression to achieve, but some might find it repetitive after a bit due to limited enemy types and environments.  This variety will of course increase as the game progresses, but waiting for that may result in a price increase later on so keep that in mind.  For this reason if you are interested it might be worth hopping in now to give it a shot.

I liked trying to hunt down hidden keys and treasure, but I hope to see this kicked up a notch with some puzzles and more interactive objects like drawers and closets.  We should be able to pick up smaller objects as well to see whats under them and throw them around, break them open, etc.

The biggest issue I had with the game currently is the online being quite buggy and laggy, I suppose this could vary from person to person, but it does state its currently in testing so results probably won't be the best for a lot of people.

Currently its not a definite yes or no purchase really, but my confidence in the developer leads me towards the yes option for now.

35508879.review:
My friend and I bought this game 2 days ago and we can't put it down!  Love the classes, love the equipment, love the skill points.  The randomization of each dungeon is so cool and I can't wait to see what kind of new rooms and things are added into the game.  I've been playing for 5 hours and from time to time will encounter a room I've never seen.  I want to say that you are doing an amazing job Blackjard and the game is already amazing without my following suggestions and ideas, but I am enjoying what you've made so much that if I can inspire you in any way with some ideas I would be honored.

My Suggestions and Ideas:

- The last room in each dungeon that has the core you need to destroy feels like it needs some kind of encounter like there is no boss at the end of the dungeon.  I mean I understand the Necromancer is basically the boss of the game and all, but just feels like the last room with the core in it needs some kind of fight, even if it's just a bunch of hard enemies or something.

- A way to heal like finding a health pot somewhere in the dungeon would be cool.  Maybe make it so that if you die, there is a little more of a harsh punishment than just respawning in the very next room, and balance it by adding rare health pots sometimes.

- Maybe some way to make the classes work together like a mage can add a fire spell to a warrior's sword and it gets a small damage buff for a short time.

- Ultimate abilities that you can unlock for Mage, Warrior, and Thief.  They would cost you a tonnnn of gold or a ton of skill pointsto unlock, and maybe only useable once per dungeon or something.  (short invulnerability for warrior, massive AOE damage spell like a meteor or something for mage, and short time of invisibility for thief or something like that).

- A feature where I can have separate save files so that I can have different characters at different levels.  I would be able to enjoy playing all the classes without completely resetting the skill points every time.  Also would allow me to play with friends who just got the game and are starting at level 1 without it feeling like I'm overpowered compared to them.  I guess would be similar to having different characters on WoW of each class.

- One of my favorite parts so far was a long corridor where you entered and the door you came through was on the floor beneath your feet, and you had to climb to the top where the next door was on the ceiling.  More of this kind of thing would be cool.  Rooms that are twisted and trippy with doors in interesting places.


I know that was a lot of suggestions, but this game really gets my mind thinking.   Just want to say again thank you, and that you are killing it with this game, please don't stop adding to this great project :]

35327083.review:
35年前にダンジョンナイトによって封印されたネクロマンサーが蘇ってしまった。世界の平和を守るために、君が新たなダンジョンナイトになるのだ！　というストーリーのダンジョンRPGです。

シングルモードと二人COOPの２種類のゲームモードがあるそうですが、COOP未プレイです。
移動方法はおなじみのワープ式の他、腕ふり移動があります。左タッチパッドで行きたい方向を触りながら腕をふることで好きな方向へシームレスに移動できます。片手の腕ふりだけで移動できるので、盾を構えながら移動や、剣を振りながらの移動も可能！グリップボタンで武器を拾ったり捨てたりでき、腰のベルトに３種、背中に１種の武器を格納できます。トリガーはアイテム（武器以外）を拾ったり、扉を開けたり、矢筒から矢を抜いたりなどのインタラクションボタンです。

ダンジョンは３種類・・・入門用低難度ダンジョン、クリアするたびに難易度が上がるダンジョン、ネクロマンサーがいる最終決戦ダンジョン。これらのダンジョンに潜り、レベルアップしたり宝箱を集めて戦力を増強していき、より上位のダンジョンに挑んでいくというのが基本ゲームプレイになります。

ダンジョン自体が薄暗く、先がほとんど見通せないため、かなりドキドキします。敵がいるか物音を聞き、曲がり角で顔だけ出して様子を窺ったりと、かなり心細く、お化け屋敷に一人おいていかれた感が強いです。グラフィックはポップだけどホラーゲームみたいな緊張感です。鍵が本棚の上に隠されていたり、左右に往復するギロチンをしゃがんでかわしたり、ツタをよじのぼって新たな道を見つけたりなど、VRの立体感をいかした仕掛けもそこそこあり、ダンジョン自体もランダム生成のようなので、繰り返し遊べそうな予感がします。

難しい攻略要素や育成の自由度などは無く、煩雑なメニュー操作もないカジュアルなゲームではありますが、
ちょっとダンジョン潜ってくるかー、みたいに気軽にプレイできそうな良作の予感がします。

ちなみに個人的な体感ですが、The Labの弓矢ゲームよりは汗をかかないくらいの運動量でした。

35192163.review:
This game is a must-have for anyone that enjoys fantasy-themed adventures. There is plenty of content for VR that focuses on gun combat, so this really stands out as a sword & sorcery experience. This game is scarier than you'd think. The cartton style would make you think that you won't be nervous playing it, but peeking around dark corners listening for that skeleton that you know will end you is truly an experience. Being able to climb certain surfaces adds to the sense of adventure, too. 

There are still some immersion breaking features. You can still just flail your arms in what I call the "blender on a stick" strategy, and the enemy's AI is pretty simple. Once one spots you, every baddy in the room comes down on you. It turns into a cycle of getting seen, and holding your ground for five minutes while everything runs into your spazzy spear. 

Plus the game generates arms and a body for you as opposed to just floating hands, which is very nice. 

Overall, this game feels like a very fleshed-out demo for something amazing. I think that VR Dungeon Knight is paving the way for how adventure games are going to be played in VR.

35078317.review:
This game is a leader on making great use of the Vive. It's like a bunch of the other games combined into a dungeon crawler. The only game I have that makes me feel like I actually travel somewhere, instead of just taking elevators or standing in a roomscale area. 

Ranged combat: Bow, crossbows, pistols. Each has its own style but all are fun to use.

Melee combat: One handed, two handed, shield, dual wield. Pick your poison and get up close and personal.

Magic combat: Staff or spellbooks. These are fun but you need to use them wisely.

Exploration: This one was the wildcard I didn't expect. Climb ivy up the walls and onto ceilings to find hidden gold or xp books. Find gold under tables and benches, behind bookcases and up on rafters. Use these to get a better position in a fight or avoid fights.

Stealth: Also unexpected. It was so intuitive, just crouch and suddenly you're harder to spot. Sneak up on or sneak around enemies. Warning: crouching through an entire dungeon can be exhausting.

Continued Support: I thought I was late to the party on this game, and yet as I opened the door to the next room I was shocked to find myself in a village instead of a dark corridor. Suddenly there was plenty of room for enemies to try and flank me, for me to sneak around patrols and for me to sprint from one enemy to the next, hacking away. Updates are still coming and they are pretty significant. The developer listens to the community and does great work. 

Conclusion: I think this game is well worth the money. I think this game is the standard others should be held up to. There is great use of the VR gear and there's a lot of stuff to keep you coming back for more. If you want an action rpg for the Vive, this is the game for you.

35040072.review:
This is definitely one of the better VR experiences, with special props for being a bit open-ended and lengthy in scope, a quite uncommon trait for VR games. It's still a little rough around the edges, but I didn't feel like I was paying a big VR tax for what I got (20$ at the time of writing).

I played this on Oculus Touch, entirely with teleportation locomotion and extensive use of snap-turning since I am not really set up for or comfortable with roomscale or smooth motion, but I still had a lot of immersive experiences. Trodding through a dark dungeon, looking out for loot and ambushing enemies, clambering up and around hanging vines (this type of motion didn't bother me), crouching  or (very rarely) going prone so I could transport through tight spaces, it gives a strong feeling of exploration.

Some caveats is I would say people with mobility issues could have trouble exploring every nook and cranny of the game or to just sneak around (the dev has stated they are looking to implement crouch-height adjustment options), but mere lack of fitness is no obstacle. I'm in terrible shape, and though I struggled a bit with an optional sub-dungeon where going fully prone was necessary (made all the more difficult by my less-than-perfect sensor coverage near the floor) I was able to make it through nonetheless, and the regular procedurally-generated dungeons have never required anything more difficult than crouching.

The difficulty curve can also be a little unpredictable. Some of the traps and terrain would be very difficult to traverse with 'arm swinger' or other smooth locomotion, but relatively easy with careful use of teleportation. Melee enemies are generally very easy except for one particularly stealthy / quick type, while ranged enemies are very deadly especially for the unprepared.

I haven't made time to play any VR games in a few weeks so I haven't tried the latest build that came out Sept 15th (I don't make much time to game at all these days), but VR Dungeon Knight is one of the titles I'd like to make more time for. They've added more rooms to explore and more gear to unlock, both things I would consider to be valuable content. Variety is already a strongpoint for this game compared to other VR titles.

I notice a lot in a lot of VR games, people have quite short hours played, and I'm definitely part of that trend. Sometimes it is due to a lack of longevity in gameplay, but I think with this game it's a factor of how the VR experience is processed. Something about it being a bit new, and also a bit strenuous, is that short play sessions feel longer and more satisfying than the kind of games I'm used to. I can hit the 5 hour mark in a traditional CRPG easily even if I'm not enjoying it, I can hit the double digits with no sweat in a strategy game I don't care for, but somehow with a VR title I love I'll play maybe an hour a day and feel that's quite sufficient. It also feels like a bigger commitment of energy and enthusiasm just getting in the mindset of booting up an active VR experience, which is probably why I've spent so little time in Robo Recall, Star Trek: Bridge Crew, H3VR, etc, even though my experience in those games and this one are definitely positive. It just isn't consumed the same way.

34804649.review:
I purchased the game about 2 hours ago with my friend, we both play on HTC Vive. 

The tutorial starts out from the very beginning, its entertaining and gives you a feel for how the rest of the game will be formatted.  The default movement requires you to swing your arms like you are walking or running, at first I wasn't sure about it, but after a few swings I realized how natural it felt. (I generally prefer locomotion over teleportation) 

The combat is lacking in fluidity, but its obvious that the combat will be great in the future due to the parry and dodge features. The difference in weapon selection really makes the combat dynamic and feel like a real adventure.  The weapon belt is a little intrusive, though it works quite well with the quiver since you can grab an arrow without even looking down.

Although the rooms and hallways are somewhat limited, you enter from different places and for the first few hours its hardly even noticable. Another thing that I am sure will be expanded.

The low variances in enemies was expected, but what I think the game could ultimately see as a striving endeavor is a stronger difference in enemy models, behaviors, and attacks.

Overall the game is great and well worth the money any day. I would like to remind you I was playing co-op the entire time and the best moments were with our weapons sheathed and crawling through tiny tunnels.

34696522.review:
This game has the ability to be really good, but I found a bug that kind of ruined it for me, and a few gameplay issues with it so far. I setup the game to use the teleport method (Which is a huge one up in my book as I am not a fan of the locomotion).

Bug:
Was perpendicular to the ground after passing through a door and I could not correct it. I had to exit the game via the oculus home screen. I was using a fire magic book and had the trigger pulled to max (Right hand). I then used my left hand to grab the door (The one with the book). When I passed in I was standing on the door. It would let me teleport on and around the door, but I could not correct my angle. So the hallway I would normally walk down appeared above my head as if I was at the bottom of a well.

Gameplay issues:
I found the enemies to be too fast moving for the weapon mechanics. There seems to be a delay in the sword swings and a big delay in the fire casting. But the enemies seem to be really fast at attacking. My only option seemed to be to hide behind a wall and try to poke out to attack. My biggest gripe is just that it seems like the enemies are too fast and also too powerful. I seemed to die after just 2-3 hits. Maybe spread out the difficulty a little more and have like a beginner mode or be more lenient at the lower levels until the mechanics can be fully realized before making it so hard.

I could not figure out how to heal. I was wounded and near death, but I had no healing ability or potions I could use. Or at least none that I could find.

I had to grab my weapons each time I died. This for me was extremely annoying as I was dying over and over trying to understand the mechanics. This was also the same for setting the difficulty of the dungeon. I understand being teleported back to the beginning again, but it felt tedious and un-necessary to have to "Reset" all of the options before I could go back into the dungeon again.

The constant blood over the eyes when "Near death" was horrible. I could hardly see and it was frustrating. Please find some other mechanic that is not so intrusive when you are low health. Or make this a temporary effect, since (and again, at least no way I could find) there seems to be no way to heal. But to have it permanently on and no way to remove it was infuriating, not to mention is strained the eyes.

The equipping of weapons is very clunky. Forget about being able to swap weapons in a fight. There should be an ability to hot swap, or re-design the "Tool belt" idea. The tool belt mechanic seems to be clunky and holding back the gameplay. I understand that it is supposed to generate immersion, but it is doing so at the cost of smooth mechanics. With as fast as the enemies seem to move, I don’t think I would ever be able to grab any other weapon on the belt. I also hate having to look down to see what I am grabbing. Then try to grab it, which I found I often would grab the wrong thing or simply drop the weapon I was holding. The belt idea might work better if it only carried two things and each trigger on the controller allowed you to grab them. Even though you could not hold as many items, it works really well in Robo Recall that way. Also Robo Recall utilizes the ability to grab something on your back. This would work great for a shield and sword for the back (Left and right shoulder) and then two items on the hips. That seemed to have a very fluid and less clunky fell to it. It also allowed you to quickly grab things as the locations of the items were very distinct, and you don’t have to look at anything, but when you put your hands to the side or shoulders you knew what weapon you were grabbing.

I know the game is early access, and I am a programmer myself, so I know the value of feedback. But these are my two cents. I think working on improving these features would have a great benefit to the game.

P.S. As far as I can tell I don't see any functionality tied to the buttons on the controller (Unless I am missing something. I am using an Oculus btw) those buttons seem like a great place to use some kind of weapon switching or inventory system to get rid of the belt.
Also, (On the Oculus Rift at least) the hands seemed to be pointing perpendicular to my own when I held the remote. When I would hold my had out in front of me with my fingers pointing forward, the in-game hands fingers seemed to be pointing up towards the wall. This is not a huge deal, but I figured it was worth mentioning.

If these issues were worked on, then I feel like this game has the potential to be great. I feel like “Not Recommended” Is a little harsh, but since I only have a choice between “Not Recommended” and “Recommended” I would have to side with the “Not Recommended just slightly more as of 9/2/17. I will be sure to update this if the experience improves. Like I said, it really does have some true potential, but, in my opinion, these things are holding it back. I hope this feedback is helpful.

34596825.review:
VR Dungeon Knight is a multiplayer dungeon crawler that may just fill that void in your VR library.

https://youtu.be/C7qKk5y8R9I

The good:

Locomotion options! Struggle through the tutorial with arm swinger and you can open up Onward style trackpad locomotion. I love that we're given several options here I just wish it could be accessed sooner. I can definitely see people getting in, seeing arm swinger and teleport and asking for a refund. It's a very extremist subject.

Full body avatars with decent IK! No more floating in space... It's not perfect but we haven't seen a perfect full body implementation yet so I don't hold that against them. At least they tried and they did a decent job.

Loot! Looks like we'll be finding weapons in chests that we get from clearing dungeons and we'll be finding gold that we can use to unlock armor with very class specific bonuses such as improved sneaking or damage resist.

Proceduraly generated dungeons keep each dive new and interesting. We also have dungeon difficulties; Normal and Nightmare. According to the bonus tracker at the end of the mission each floor has a sub boss to find and kill so exploration is rewarded.

One of the things I've seen while playing after the initial gameplay video was that some of the randomly generated rooms are vertical. You'll walk into a room and will only be able to climb up to a hatch at the top of the room periodically needing to stop climbing and walk across a beam to start climbing on the other side. It was a nice rare experience.

Some of my issues with the game:

As I mentioned above. Being forced into arm swinger at the start of the game isn't the best idea IMO. Give us the option at the start of the game.

Speaking of the start of the game, don't just dump us into a cinematic as soon as the game starts. Wait for some interaction on our part. This one is more a pet peeve for me as I think most people start the game with the HMD on already but still...

While reviewing the footage, the music seems a little too Mad Hatter, bright and happy in the beginning that doesn't seem to mesh with the surroundings in some areas. I didn't really notice i in game though.

While we're on audio... Some of the sound effects are much louder than they should be. Mostly around magic which I ended up not using much of in this video.

It's going to be a bit grindy. You'll need to bring a friend to stave off some of that repetitious feeling. No friends? You better love the crawl as you'll find no story here to distract from the grind.

Most importantly, there are some game breaking bugs. At the end of the video I fall off the bridge and needed to exit the game and restart the game. While in one of the dungeons I fell through the floor and nearly got stuck. These need to get fixed sooner rather than later.

No quit button!

Ultimately I'm somewhat neutral on the game but leaning towards a thumbs up in spite of some of its faults because I did enjoy myself in the end. I think the game will be more enjoyable with a friend but if you like dungeon crawling this should scratch that VR itch.

I would love it if we could create our own dungeons and populate it with monsters we've defeated and have others play through our work. For some reason it just seems like it would fit here.

34538850.review:
In my mind, people may look back at this as the "Everquest of VR". It's that moment where systems finally come together to produce the game that will likely be a blueprint for many future products. Are you a sneaky sneak, or a bashy basher, perhaps a fire slingin' finger wiggler? It's all here, and you can mix and match to your hearts content! Let's hit the critical points here:

[b]Highlights:[/b][list]
[*]Co-op mode absolutely shines! The game encourages specialization and teamwork.

[*]Full range of motion is used to navigate environments. You WILL climb vines, swing across poles over gaping chasms, get on the ground and crawl through tight cave spaces. The world is wonderfully immersive and fun to interact with!

[*]One of the most responsive, kind, and interactive developers you will ever see. Have suggestions? He wants em. Hit a bug? He's on it. Player input is wanted and acted on, and it shows. This is clearly a passion project. The game grows at an amazing pace for a single developer. These are the kinds of folks that are worth supporting![/list]

[b]Closing Thoughts[/b]
I was going to write a "Needs Improvement" section, but the truth is, for an Early Access product it's already more complete than many games with far larger budgets and development resources! The developer is highly responsive and completely engaged with this project, so things will only get better from here... and here, well, here is pretty solid already!

I'm 12 hours in, with many more to come. It's a joy to watch this one develop... I think this could be a classic!

34491504.review:
PLAY THIS GAME

I was amazed to learn that this game is developed by one dude.  I was so impressed I'm writing a review.  I never write reviews.  

As far as VR games go, this is a great one.  One of the only VR games that has me daydreaming about playing it while I'm at work.  

Spooky dungeons, good ambient sounds and combat music, A STEALTH MECHANIC (rad!), and a relatively fun loot system.  The monsters look cool, too.  Seeing an orc's glowing eyes and hearing the heavy footsteps in in the pitch black dark of the dungeon as he shambles towards me gives me a thrill every time.

Weapon System - You have to load yourself out in the weapon room before every dungeon.  This is to avoid multiplayer bugs, but I actually LIKE having to arm myself before each run.  Adds a little immersion.  I believe an automatic loudout system is planned for the future.   Various ranged, melee and magic weapons are available to unlock.  All fun to use, imho.  VR Lantern Knight ftw

Loot System - You can find gold in the dungeons, which you can purchase new armor with.  The armor looks cool when you wear it and gives you bonuses based on stealth, magic, archery, and damage reduction. At the end of each dungeon you get a set amount of treasure chests (with possibility of a bonus) that give you weapons as well as level upgrades for those weapons.  Overall pretty rewarding, but it would be cool to be able to find treasure chests on the ground in dungeons as well.

Fighting System - Pretty good fighting, but things can get a little weird in close quarters.  Sometimes if I was too close to a monster, my swings wouldn't register until I backed up a bit.  Nothing gamebreaking at all, you just gotta get used to the optimal fighting distance at first.   Fun sword/shield combat.   The monsters don't seem to swing their weapons the same way every time.  I don't know if this is good coding or what, but if I just hold my shield in one general place, they eventually swing around it and hit me.   Cool.   At first, I thought monsters only attacked you one at a time, but if they can come down another hallway and flank you, you'll be takin it from both sides.  But lets be honest, you're used to that.

Climbing Mechanic - This is cool!  You can clammer up vines found peppered throughout the dungeons that lead to loot, keys to unlock the next room, alternate exits, or just a sneaky archer/thief/caster spot.   It's one of my favorite features.   

Stealth System - Crouch to go into stealth mode, your screen turns blue and your movement slows a bit.  Enemies take a bit longer to detect you.  Seems to be effected by the ambient lighting, which is cool, but unconfirmed.  Sometimes the bastards just see me.  Stealth kills seem to work with every weapon (spells? I dunno yet) and stabbing them in the face seems to be best practice.  I THINK the vines that you can climb on can also act as camoflauge, making you harder to see.  This is totally rad.  I was hanging from ceiling vines, obscured by vines below me as monsters hustled around directly beneath me.  10/10 would vine again.  Stealth kills give you bonus chest, which is most triumphant.  (air guitar)

Oh, and its Co-Op.

I have to say, I don't review many games, but this one deserves a good one. I know it is always iffy to spend money on early access games, but I believe the developer is doing this the right way. I really want to see this game succeed.

First, he is extremely active on the forums, and seem very open to ideas and feedback. In what little time I've had it, I've already seen 2 updates implementing commonly requested features or fixes.

Second, the game has a good, simple foundation that makes it fun to play. Randomized dungeons, and a variety of weapons that feel great to use. There are multiple options for movement (teleport or free running), not to mention crawling and climbing.

There are a few cons of course. It can be a bit tough to pick some objects up when the environment gets in the way. And while the dark dungeons are suspenseful, I wouldn't mind a few well lit sections to appreciate the scenery better. 

All in all its an easy recommendation. If you enjoy dungeon crawls, or RPGs, go for it. You won't regret it.

Oh and it runs perfectly for me. I'm playing on an Oculus Rift, i7-4790k, GTX 980, and an SSD.

Ziel von VR Dungeon Knight ist es, zufällig generierte Verliese zu bezwingen. Dazu schleicht und metzelt man sich durch verschiedene Gegner und Minibosse, sammelt Gold und Loot ein und lvlt seinen Charakter hoch. Später kann man sein Gold noch einsetzten, um sich klassenspezifisch zu verbessern. Zusätzlich erhöht man noch das Level seiner Waffen und Ausrüstungsgegenstände (Schwerter, Dolche, Schusswaffen, Schilde, Laternen usw.)
Dabei hat man die Wahl, ob man als Magier, Krieger oder "Schleicher" vorgeht um das Ende der Verliese zu erreichen. Und das sogar im Koop, wenn man möchte, definitiv ein Pluspunkt. 
Zusätzlich kann man sich zwischen 2 Schwierigkeitsgraden bei den normalen Dungeons entscheiden und es gibt noch ein Endbossverlies.

Die Grafik ist angemessen und macht einen guten Eindruck. Das Spiel läuft sehr flüssig (GTX970, i5, Supersampling 1,5)

Ein kleines Tutorial wäre vielleicht noch ganz nett gewesen, da ich am Anfang nicht begriffen habe, was es mit den Laternen auf sich hat, ansonsten ist das Spiel selbsterklärend.

Da das Spiel ständig erweitert wird und durch die zufällig generierten Dungeons und das Lvln der Ausrüstung und des Charakters auch einen Wiederspielwert besitzt, für mich eine klare Kaufempfehlung.

OK I have had this game for a long time, played once thought it was ok and then never got round to playing again. For what reason I don't know, honestly I have a lot of games and I think I just forgot about it. Recently someone asked me what I thought of it, I replied I couldn't really remember it and will try it again and see.

Thank God I did, this is a pretty good Dungeon crawler and very underrated game. Why more people are not playing this I don't know as it is one of the better games for the Vive out there. It can be dark, forbidding and really give you a chill if playing alone but the game comes alive with co-op. 

There are multiple weapons with levels, costumes, upgrades on abilities and the ability to become the type of fighter you want to be. Mage, warrior, archer or just a plain old Ye Olde Rambo. The battles can be hectic or attack from afar, the dungeons change and you're always on the lookout for gold or weapons.

I don't know why I have not played this more but it is in my top ten Vive games now and will be playing much more. Trouble sometimes buying a lot of games you don't give some a real chance and miss out on a good game now and then.

Recommend if you liked Vanishing realms or like to play dungeon crawlers on a monitor, really is amazing how far we have come. Remember playing Diablo and thinking it would be great to be in the game, well now we can.

I understand that this game is Early Access, but, at the moment, it's borderline unplayable for me.  

Each time I would start playing it after having logged out of Steam VR previously, I would have to force-exit (no actualy in-game exit) and re-run the Steam VR Room setup to recalibrate the floor.  Don't know why, it just kept thinking that I'm about 12 feet tall and I couldn't reach anything on the floor.

Additionally, the first bit of the game took me a good 10 minutes just to figure out how to acknowledge the speaking critter.  It didn't tell me to click my thumbstick--that was an alien thought to me.  Why not use A or B, or X or Y?  Nope.  Thumbstick.

The turning controls were VERY twitchy, most of the time it took five or more clicks before I would turn, and by then, I was dead.

Also, I didn't like having to lay on my floor to do reach under chairs for keys.  Coupled with the fact that this game kept thinking my floor was several feet further down than it really was . . ..  I can't reach into my basement from my bedroom.

Reading that the dev isn't making enough off of this game is disheartening.  I'm very sorry for him, but, this game is just too unfinished for me to continue trying to play.

Good luck.

34267460.review:
It has bugs in co-op and some general bugs. However, if you don't mind having to reboot the game a few times in a good 1-2 hour session it really is a fantastic game.

The dev is pretty responsive and you can look in the discussions he basically tries to address every concern or feedback in some way.

If you have a friend that buys this it really is a blast. There is a real sense of progression to unlock all the weapons, level up for new attributes, find and save gold to buy "classes" (suits of armor with pretty good special abilities).

I really really enjoy it. Sometimes spells are super fun, bow and arrow sneak attacks, dagger sneak attacks.... Having to actually duck and prone under some obstacles or to get gold. Crawling around with ivy. Poke enemies with your spear or smack em around with your great sword. Just fun stuff!

It most reminds me of a less polished Vanishing Realms with procedural generated dungeons that you can co-op with a friend in. It's just so much fun to joke around and wail on enemies together or sneak attack enemies while ducking behind cover together, etc.

The combat is simplistic at the moment, but single player is pretty challenging since some rooms can have like 3-6 enemies with ranged attacks or melee attacks that can be difficult to parry and dodge if you are careless.

I really can't wait for more content from the developer.

TLDR - If you liked Vanishing Realms and have a friend or don't mind playing with random people it really is quite a blast in co-op. Single-player can be fun too since it really is quite creepy and you can basically play several different ways with the weapons and armor you choose.

From the birth of video games in the 70’s, a time when RPG’s were mostly played on pen and paper in the realm of imagination, gamers have had a dream, nay, a vision, of a future when gamers could don their armor, memorize their spells, and delve into a dungeon together with friends, in virtual reality.

Today, gamers, rejoice in rapture, for the long awaited promise of the future has arrived. It is truly a glorious age to be an RPG gamer, for today, you can enter virtual reality with your friends and delve the depths of fully realized dungeons with traps, monsters and secret areas to explore. VR Dungeon Knight, after so many years, has taken up the banner and answered the call to provide gamers the experience that so many have sought for so long.

Ladies and gentlemen, the Multiplayer VR dungeon crawl is here. Buy it or miss out on a transformational title in gaming. 

Disclaimer: It is an early access, first (modern) gen VR game, which shows a lot of promise but still has a few things to work out and develop. That said, it seems to be the most legit and fun game of its type on Steam. It isn’t Skyrim in VR, but adds things to the VR experience that makes it well worth a try. It’s currently only 2 person MP. If you can accept the in-development status, see the promise of future development, and the above paragraph resonates with you, then this game is absolutely a must have.

34237527.review:
If you want to bro out with someone and dungeon crawl, this game is for you. 

If you're looking for complex mazes, deep combat, lots of secret hunting (beyond finding gold piles in nooks and crannies) then AS OF RIGHT NOW it's not there YET

Still, even as a dreaded [i] Early Access [/i] title it's got a lot of really amazingly good parts. I'll just do it in list style otherwise I'm going to write a book.

1. The multiplayer is amazing. You're at the top of the stairs with a sword and board. Your mage partner is behind you. Arrows flying at you both from the skeleton archers below but you're pro status and blocking that shit with your buckler. You got an orc coming up the stairs and your partner says move right. You do, you see a flash of magic fly past your head with a booming sound. That skeleton archer is dust. The orc swings but you catch it with your sword for a parry. You throw some swings in and move again while your mage turns them into plasma. That fight's over, but you hear footsteps in the distance..

2. Minor boss spoiler. [spoiler] If you've played the Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of time and remember the Shadow Ganon fight where you swing your sword at a magic orb and knock it back and forth until it hits him? It's better in VR. [/spoiler]

3. Good variety of weapons and play styles. Stealth? Yes. Magic? Yes. Tank? Yes. 

4. This hallway is impassible because of this huge hole in the ground. Oh wait, there's some vines on the walls, I wonder if I can climb them...

For the multiplayer alone this game is absolutely solid. If there are negatives I would say these are them.

1. Can't fight on stairs. You hit the floor trying to block enemies that start swinging at your feet coming up the stairs. 

2. The larger enemies can clip into you sometimes, and their swings clip through walls. You need a clear face to face path to fight effectively. 

3. Multiple archer fights require a bit of balance for melee fighters. You move close to one archer and he draws his dagger, you parry his swing only to get shot in the face by an archer almost every single time, leaving you no room to really deal with this situation. Only shields currently are bucklers which are very small and hard to block fast moving arrows with. 

4. Some significant bugs. I died in the middle of a fight with four archers (refrencing the above point.) My 'ghost' or whatever could still move around and could body block all of the arrows coming at my partner. It allowed us to complete the room but clearly it's an issue. 

5. Need some way to heal our team mates. So far if you die, you're dead until your teammate opens a door to progress the dungeon. 


Even with these flaws, this game is a winning bet. The price point is good. The game is fantastic on your own. It's  a must have with the multiplayer. If you want to dungeon crawl, this game is it for VR.
